Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = \\nabla^2 u \\), commonly referred to as the heat equation. An integral transform, specifically the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x, t)) = U(k, t) \\), is applied to the system.

If we apply the Fourier transform to the initial condition \\( u(x, 0) \\) and then let the system evolve according to the heat equation, will \\( U(k, t) \\) at time \\( t = T \\) be equivalent to direct application of the heat equation followed by the Fourier transform at \\( t = T \\)?
Explanation: The linearity and time-invariance of the heat equation allow the Fourier transform to commute with the time evolution operator of the system. Thus, transforming first and then evolving the system or evolving first and then transforming will yield the same result in the frequency domain at any time \\( t = T \\).
